text: The prophecy of Nahum is primarily an oracle concerning the downfall of which city?
verseText: An oracle concerning Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum of Elkosh.

text: How is the LORD described in Nahum 1:2-3?
options: Jealous, avenging, wrathful, but also slow to anger and great in power
verseText: The LORD is a jealous and avenging God; the LORD is avenging and wrathful... The LORD is slow to anger and great in power, and the LORD will by no means clear the guilty.

text: While God is slow to anger, Nahum 1:3 emphasizes that He will by no means do what?
verseText: The LORD is slow to anger and great in power, and the LORD will by no means clear the guilty.

text: Despite the focus on judgment against Nineveh, what comfort does Nahum 1:7 offer?
options: The LORD is a stronghold in the day of trouble; He knows those who take refuge in Him
verseText: The LORD is good, a stronghold in the day of trouble; he knows those who take refuge in him.

text: Nahum 1:15 brings good news specifically to which kingdom?
verseText: Behold, upon the mountains, the feet of him who brings good news, who publishes peace! Keep your feasts, O Judah; fulfill your vows, for never again shall the worthless pass through you; he is utterly cut off.

text: Chapters 2 and 3 vividly describe what aspect of Nineveh?
options: Its impending siege, battle, destruction, and wickedness
verseText: (Describes the attack, chariots, bloodshed, plunder, and reasons for judgment like cruelty and idolatry)

text: Nineveh is referred to metaphorically as what kind of city in Nahum 3:1?
verseText: Woe to the bloody city, all full of lies and plunder— no end to the prey!

text: What reason is given in Nahum 3:4 for Nineveh's judgment related to its influence on nations?
verseText: And all for the countless whorings of the prostitute, graceful and of deadly charms, who betrays nations with her whorings, and peoples with her witchcraft.

text: Nahum compares Nineveh's fate to the previous fall of which great Egyptian city?
verseText: Are you better than Thebes (No-amon) that sat by the Nile, with water around her, her rampart a sea, and water her wall?

text: What is the final, bleak assessment of Nineveh's situation in Nahum 3:19?
options: There is no healing for its wound; all who hear the news clap their hands
verseText: There is no easing your hurt; your wound is grievous. All who hear the news about you clap their hands over you. For upon whom has not come your unceasing evil?

text: What does Nahum's name likely mean?
verseText: (The name Nahum relates to the Hebrew word for comfort, fitting as the book comforts Judah with news of Nineveh's fall).

text: Nahum 1:3 describes the LORD's path being in what?
verseText: ...His way is in whirlwind and storm, and the clouds are the dust of his feet.

text: What natural elements does Nahum 1:4 say the LORD rebukes and controls?
options: The sea, rivers, Bashan, Carmel, Lebanon
verseText: He rebukes the sea and makes it dry; he dries up all the rivers; Bashan and Carmel wither; the bloom of Lebanon withers.

text: How do the mountains and hills react to the LORD's presence in Nahum 1:5?
verseText: The mountains quake before him; the hills melt; the earth heaves before him, the world and all who dwell in it.

text: Who can stand before the LORD's indignation and fierce anger, according to Nahum 1:6?
verseText: Who can stand before his indignation? Who can endure the heat of his anger? His wrath is poured out like fire, and the rocks are broken into pieces by him.

text: What will happen to Nineveh, according to Nahum 1:8?
options: It will become a place of refuge
An overwhelming flood will make a full end of its site
verseText: But with an overwhelming flood he will make a full end of her site, and darkness will pursue his enemies.

text: What does God promise to break from Judah in Nahum 1:13?
verseText: And now I will break his yoke from off you and will burst your bonds apart.”

text: What command does God give concerning Nineveh (specifically its king/idols) in Nahum 1:14?
options: No more descendants will bear its name; idols will be cut off; a grave prepared
They will be moved to Judah
They will be given to Babylon
verseText: The LORD has given commandment about you: “No more shall your name be perpetuated; from the house of your gods I will cut off the carved image and the metal image. I will make your grave, for you are vile.”

text: Who is 'the scatterer' coming up against Nineveh in Nahum 2:1?
verseText: The scatterer has come up against you. Man the ramparts; watch the road; dress for battle; collect all your strength.

text: What colors are associated with the shields and uniforms of Nineveh's attackers in Nahum 2:3?
verseText: The shield of his mighty men is red; his soldiers are clothed in scarlet. The chariots flash like flame when mustered in array; the cypress spears are brandished.

text: How are the chariots described moving in the streets and squares during the attack (Nahum 2:4)?
options: Raging, dashing to and fro, flashing like torches, darting like lightning
verseText: The chariots race madly through the streets; they rush to and fro through the squares; they gleam like torches; they dart like lightning.

text: What happens when the Ninevite officers are summoned (Nahum 2:5)?
options: They stumble in their march and rush to the wall
verseText: He remembers his officers; they stumble as they go; they hasten to the wall; the siege tower is set up.

text: What key part of Nineveh's defenses is opened, leading to the palace melting (Nahum 2:6)?
verseText: The river gates are opened; the palace melts away;

text: How are the slave girls of Nineveh depicted mourning in Nahum 2:7?
options: Moaning like doves and beating their breasts
verseText: its mistress is stripped; she is carried off, her slave girls lamenting, moaning like doves and beating their breasts.

text: Nineveh is compared to what failing structure in Nahum 2:8?
options: A leaking pool of water whose waters run away
verseText: Nineveh is like a pool whose waters run away. “Halt! Halt!” they cry, but none turns back.

text: What are the invaders encouraged to do in Nahum 2:9?
options: Plunder the silver and gold, for there is no end to the treasure
verseText: Plunder the silver, plunder the gold! There is no end of the treasure or wealth of every precious thing.

text: What three words describe the state of Nineveh after the plunder in Nahum 2:10?
verseText: Desolate! Desolation and ruin! Hearts melt and knees tremble; anguish is in all loins; all faces grow pale!

text: Nineveh, the Assyrian capital, is metaphorically asked 'Where is the lions' den?' in Nahum 2:11-12. Why?
options: Lions were kept in the palace zoo
Assyria was known for its lion-like ferocity and predatory nature
verseText: Where is the lions' den, the feeding place of the young lions, where the lion and lioness went, where his cubs were, with none to disturb? The lion tore enough for his cubs and strangled prey for his lionesses; he filled his caves with prey and his dens with torn flesh.

text: Who declares 'I am against you' to Nineveh in Nahum 2:13?
verseText: Behold, I am against you, declares the LORD of hosts, and I will burn your chariots in smoke, and the sword shall devour your young lions. I will cut off your prey from the earth, and the voice of your messengers shall no longer be heard.

text: Besides being a 'bloody city', Nineveh is described as full of what in Nahum 3:1?
verseText: Woe to the bloody city, all full of lies and plunder— no end to the prey!

text: What sounds of battle are vividly described in Nahum 3:2-3?
options: Whip cracks, rumbling wheels, galloping horses, bounding chariots, horsemen charging, flashing swords, glittering spears, heaps of slain
verseText: The crack of the whip, and rumble of the wheel, galloping horse and bounding chariot! Horsemen charging, flashing sword and glittering spear, hosts of slain, heaps of corpses, dead bodies without end— they stumble over the bodies!

text: What degrading action does God say He will perform against Nineveh because of her 'whorings' (Nahum 3:5)?
options: Lift her skirts over her face and show nations her nakedness
verseText: Behold, I am against you, declares the LORD of hosts, and will lift up your skirts over your face; and I will make nations look at your nakedness and kingdoms at your shame.

text: What was the fate of Thebes (No-amon) that serves as a warning to Nineveh (Nahum 3:10)?
options: It went into exile and captivity; its infants were dashed in pieces
It formed an alliance with Assyria
verseText: Yet she became an exile; she went into captivity; her infants were dashed in pieces at the head of every street; for her honored men lots were cast, and all her great men were bound in chains.

text: How are Nineveh's fortresses described in Nahum 3:12?
options: As fig trees with ripe figs that fall when shaken
verseText: All your fortresses are like fig trees with first-ripe figs— if shaken they fall into the mouth of the eater.

text: How are Nineveh's troops described in Nahum 3:13?
options: As women; the gates are open to enemies; fire consumes the bars
verseText: Behold, your troops are women in your midst. The gates of your land are wide open to your enemies; fire has devoured your bars.

text: What futile defensive measures is Nineveh sarcastically told to undertake in Nahum 3:14?
options: Draw water for the siege, strengthen defenses, tread clay, take hold of brick mold
verseText: Draw water for the siege; strengthen your forts; go into the clay; tread the mortar; take hold of the brick mold!

text: How are Nineveh's merchants and princes/commanders described in Nahum 3:16-17?
options: Like locusts that multiply and then fly away when trouble comes
verseText: You multiplied your merchants more than the stars of heaven. The locust spreads its wings and flies away. Your princes are like grasshoppers, your scribes like clouds of locusts settling on the fences in a cold day— when the sun rises, they fly away...

text: What is the state of Nineveh's shepherds (leaders) according to Nahum 3:18?
options: They are slumbering; the people are scattered
verseText: Your shepherds are asleep, O king of Assyria; your nobles slumber. Your people are scattered on the mountains with none to gather them.

text: Why do all who hear the news of Nineveh's fall clap their hands (Nahum 3:19)?
options: Because Nineveh's unceasing evil had affected everyone
verseText: All who hear the news about you clap their hands over you. For upon whom has not come your unceasing evil?
